title: Return/resolve actual newly created/updated item from store
body: We are returning the actual newly created/updated item as returned from store. Best explained with an example: If we pass `{name: 'dojo'}` to `store.newItem()`, then we might get something like `{id: 99, name: 'dojo', 'date_created': ...}` returned from well-built REST server. Now that we have a deferred/promise here (since last commit), we would expect the resolved value to be the new value (as in `item`) returned from server (or whatever returned by the store), but not our original input (as in `object`). Without this fix, data consumers may get incomplete object which differs from actual store structure.

title: allow debounce to be bound
body:
the existing debounce implementation attempts to bind the callback to this, but in the context of the setTimeout function, that is always Window.

this PR binds the setTimeout function to the context of the outer function, which allows the result of debounce to be bound to a context, just as throttle allows.

title: Stateful fixes
body:
I have some gripes with Stateful. Here are some tests that demonstrate the issues, and fixes in Stateful.

* the new value reported in callbacks is not the actual new value of the instance
* callbacks are also called when the property didn't change
* we need a definition of change and no change

I would like feedback on this.

Does it make any sense to continue on this path?

title: fx: different timers for different rates
body:
if different rates are used for fx animations at the same time the timer will take the rate entry of the first animations playing.
this might screw up some animations.
this patch provides different timers for each rate.

title: dojo/store/observable/* Proposal
body:
The following changes constitute my proposal for an alternative observable store API [as documented here](https://github.com/Zarillion/dojo/wiki/dojo.store.observable-Stores). This could be used to solve a number of outstanding bugs in the dgrid project, including [this one](https://github.com/SitePen/dgrid/issues/714#issuecomment-25843753) in which this sort of observable implementation was first discussed. Some aspects of the design: 

* Materialized queries eliminate the need for results to be filtered and sorted prior to each page request
* Consistent start/count values for pages; only pages which overlap with the bottom of the query are allowed to be incomplete
* Well defined and heavily tested page-update events
* Shared implementations for materialized queries and pages used by both Memory and JsonRest
* Consistent ordering of changes for remote stores; support for websocket-based updates

The Memory implementation is very much plug-n-play. Users of existing observable Memory stores will need to adjust their paging logic to account for the new approach to `start` and `count` consistency.

JsonRest users will need to implement a number of additional views. They will be responsible for maintaining materialized queries and keeping track of which pages the client is currently interested in. Each time a change is made, `changeRecord` objects will need to be created for each active subscription and served to the client when requested. The API documentation describes what information should be included in each `changeRecord` object under any possible update scenario. It requires more server-side code to send the updates to the client than the older JsonRest protocol, but the payoff is data consistency and simplicity in the front-end.

Please let me know what you think regarding this type of approach.

title: Changes for #17285. Fixed pause to account for pausing during delay period. Introduced resume function.
body: Changes for [#17285](https://bugs.dojotoolkit.org/ticket/17285). The pause function did not handle the initial delay portion. This change fixes that. Basically if the animation had a delay to start and if the pause was issued on that during the period when it is waiting for the animation to start and then when the animation was restarted using gotopercent the delay started all over again. This is fixed now. Also introduced a resume function to resume the animation and the delay from where it was stopped.
